channel.title: OpenRSCD: RSClassic server emulator written in C
channel.description:
Hi all, just figured I'd share this project with the community. Here is the link to the ISC licensed(do what the fudge you want with it, but give credit) project: https://github.com/Zlacki/OpenRSCD I've been working on this off and on for a while now, not made much headway yet, but more than others seem to have. I am using a modified 202 client with much improvements bringing JDK requirement to 1.6, which I will upload to github as well, soon.
I would love contributions with merge requests, and would appreciate any modifications you make be released, but this isn't necessary by licensing.
Some plans: Keep improving the client, improve cache format, make proper walking work on the server, select regions from a hashmap(I may have tackled that already), eventually port the client to C too.
Design improvement ideas are VERY MUCH welcomed, and I will listen to anyone that offers help.
Pic of logging in with loading regions and wearing items with bonuses registering: [img]https://cirnopk.com/progress.png[/img]
Walking is not done yet, but when you click to walk you teleport around for now. That is next on my todo list.

item.source: OpenRSCD: RSClassic server emulator written in C

item.title: OpenRSCD: RSClassic server emulator written in C
item.dc:creator: @Zlacki Zlacki
item.description:
@Zlacki wrote:

The Enforcer:

I read your blog one day. Why did you get a fast food job to pay your debts? Why don’t you do freelance or get a real job as a developer? Although getting a real job in that area might not be as easy for you as I can imagine you do not have a degree.

I do contract work a lot, just need extra money lately is all.

I am migrating this project to either Objective-C or C++, as a server of this design lends itself well to object orientation and both of said language implementations I’ll be using are practically the same in resource usage as C.
This’ll probably be a total rewrite of the RSC module, maybe remove the modularity as I don’t plan on doing much that is besides RSC anymore, and can just modify it in the future if I change my mind.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenRSCD: RSClassic server emulator written in C
item.dc:creator: @Zlacki Zlacki
item.description:
@Zlacki wrote:

Lothy:

Stop getting caught up with minutiae.

Minutiae hardly IMO; style is important.
I’m working on a Java source right now based on Stork’s VarekD so I’m a bit occupied lately to work on OpenRSCD.

item.title: OpenRSCD: RSClassic server emulator written in C
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“Zlacki, post:15, topic:537132”][quote author=The Enforcer link=topic=655945.msg4392528#msg4392528 date=1388038091]

you allowed the Enforcer to troll you to change your braces?.. rep–;

Re-read my posts and re-read the code; that’s a style change I’ve made myself on all of my projects yet to hit my github

At least things are moving, you have changed the brace style on functions as I directed. But the other braces too. You haven’t checked in any code for 6 days, what is going on!? Also I don’t like: a) pointer star position, b) memset first argument is casted to char*, why? it accepts void*, c) no space between if/etc and braces. I can’t give you too many tasks at a time, you haven’t proven yourself yet.
[/quote]
The whole point of that change is to isolate functions easily in ViM.[/quote]

But perhaps you subconsciously still thought that brace style is better and you’re trying to justify it with some other reasons because your conscious mind is not ready to accept it yet.

Read full topic

you allowed the Enforcer to troll you to change your braces?.. rep–;

Re-read my posts and re-read the code; that’s a style change I’ve made myself on all of my projects yet to hit my github
[/quote]

At least things are moving, you have changed the brace style on functions as I directed. But the other braces too. You haven’t checked in any code for 6 days, what is going on!? Also I don’t like: a) pointer star position, b) memset first argument is casted to char*, why? it accepts void*, c) no space between if/etc and braces. I can’t give you too many tasks at a time, you haven’t proven yourself yet.[/quote]
The whole point of that change is to isolate functions easily in ViM.

item.title: OpenRSCD: RSClassic server emulator written in C
item.dc:creator: @Zlacki Zlacki
item.description:
@Zlacki wrote:

[quote=“sspoke, post:8, topic:537132”]Should make people who login with rs2 module be able to be seen in rsc world and vice-versa don’t know if the map coordinates match though.

should move hashmap/hashset/list etc into like a collections folder or something

found a potential bug in rand256

 static unsigned const limit = RAND_MAX - RAND_MAX % 256;

isn’t that always going to be 0?[/quote]
Yes it is, thanks for pointing it out for me!

Rodgerwilco:

Have you taken a look at lothys c server?

Yea I’ve seen it, but did not use any of the code for reference or inspiration. Not that the code was bad–I just went another design route.

The Enforcer:

Someone should beat you up for using that brace style in C.

You mean best brace style? I think everyone agrees it’s almost perfect, minus the lack of newlines on functions.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenRSCD: RSClassic server emulator written in C
item.dc:creator: @Zlacki Zlacki
item.description:
@Zlacki wrote:

[quote=“eXemplar, post:6, topic:537132”]Neat.

Any particular reason you’re doing a lot of dynamic allocations and list lookups?[/quote]
I’d say habitual reasons, but really I didn’t think I used either in cases where they weren’t needed. Perhaps I am wrong.
Very least I only use List’s where I felt it was necessary, I may have gone overboard in dynamic allocs, but that is habit.

Read full topic

item.title: OpenRSCD: RSClassic server emulator written in C
item.dc:creator: @Zlacki Zlacki
item.description:
@Zlacki wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:4, topic:537132”]Okay.

I decided to restart my rsc-c project last night. It’s 100x times better than the previous model so far. I decided, once again, to use lacewing as the networking platform, although should I wish to change that in the future (since lacewing seems very unstable at this point) I will be/am using dependency injection in certain aspects of the project.

I’ll be uploading it to github once I get a little further along.[/quote]
I’m using libev which I battled with libev vs libevent for I/O handling, chose libev and it is portable enough for my needs.

Read full topic

I decided to restart my rsc-c project last night. It’s 100x times better than the previous model so far. I decided, once again, to use lacewing as the networking platform, although should I wish to change that in the future (since lacewing seems very unstable at this point) I will be/am using dependency injection in certain aspects of the project.

I’ll be uploading it to github once I get a little further along.

You’ll have to wait a little til I get home, but yes soon I will. I think you’ll like the modifications thus far.
